label: Nov 20 â€“ 21, 1963 Â· Dallas, TX
title: The Ralph Leon Yates Incident
description: Ralph Leon Yates reported picking up a hitchhiker on Nov 20, but FBI alibi checks suggest the event likely occurred on Nov 21. Both dates are preserved here for analysis of potential Oswald movements.
context: The Ralph Yates incident represents one of the most compelling witness accounts of a possible Oswald sighting before the JFK assassination. Yates, a refrigeration mechanic, reported picking up a hitchhiker matching Oswald's description who carried a package and discussed shooting the President from a window. The FBI conducted extensive interviews but ultimately determined discrepancies in Yates' timeline. Yates later experienced a mental health crisis and was hospitalized. The case remains disputed among researchers.

sub_events.label: Nov 21, 1963 Â· Irving, TX
sub_events.title: Park-It Market Service Call (Verified)
sub_events.description: Ralph Yates performed a verified refrigeration service call at Park-It Market Drive-In Grocery, 2320 Shady Grove Road, Irving TX. He was dispatched around 10:30 AM, called in after 11:30 AM, and returned to TBSC around 12:30-1:00 PM. The compressor was out of oil. Documented by Shop Bill No. 8760, Invoice No. 36919 ($12.00 for 2-hour call).

sub_events.label: Nov 26, 1963
sub_events.title: First Yates Report
sub_events.description: Ralph Leon Yates voluntarily contacts the Dallas FBI office to report picking up a hitchhiker he believes was Lee Harvey Oswald carrying a package of 'curtain rods'.

sub_events.label: Nov 27, 1963
sub_events.title: Formal FBI Interview
sub_events.description: Yates appears at the FBI office with his uncle, J.O. Smith. He details the hitchhiker's questions about shooting the President from a window. Agents Arthur Carter and C. Ray Hall conduct the interview.

sub_events.label: Nov 27, 1963 Â· Dallas, TX
sub_events.title: Dempsey Jones FBI Interview
sub_events.description: FBI Special Agent Arthur E. Carter interviewed Dempsey Jones at Route 4, Box 376, Dallas TX. Jones confirmed Yates told him about the hitchhiker before the assassination. He described Yates as 'a big talker who always talks about a lot of foolishness.' Jones said Yates mentioned the man had a package and discussed shooting the President from a building.

sub_events.label: Nov 27, 1963 Â· Dallas, TX
sub_events.title: J.R. Gilpin FBI Interview
sub_events.description: FBI interviewed J.R. Gilpin, partner at Texas Butchers Supply Company. Gilpin located Shop Bill No. 8760 and Invoice No. 36919 documenting Yates' service call to Park-It Market in Irving on November 21, 1963. He confirmed dispatching Yates around 10:30 AM and calling him at the market around noon.

sub_events.label: Dec 10, 1963
sub_events.title: Signed Statement & Photo ID
sub_events.description: Yates provides a sworn affidavit to SA C. Ray Hall. He positively identifies a photo of Oswald. He adds details about the hitchhiker showing him a picture of a man with a rifle.

sub_events.label: Jan 3, 1964
sub_events.title: Alibi Verification Check
sub_events.description: FBI Agents re-interview Yates regarding discrepancies in his service call timeline. They confront him with the lack of a check stub from Charlie's Meat Market.

sub_events.label: Jan 3, 1964 Â· Dallas, TX
sub_events.title: Thomas Ayres FBI Interview
sub_events.description: FBI Special Agent John T. Kesler interviewed Thomas Ayres at Charlie's Ranch Meat Market, 249 Wynnewood Village. Ayres was on duty November 20-21, 1963 but could not recall giving a check to a TBSC employee. He reviewed check stubs with negative results. Stated only one check is issued to TBSC each month.

sub_events.label: Jan 3, 1964 Â· Dallas, TX
sub_events.title: Donald Mask FBI Interview
sub_events.description: FBI Special Agent John T. Kesler interviewed Donald Mask at Charlie's Ranch Meat Market. Mask was on duty November 21, 1963 but could not recall giving a check to a TBSC employee. Like Ayres, he confirmed only one check is typically issued to TBSC each month.

sub_events.label: Jan 4, 1964
sub_events.title: Polygraph Examination
sub_events.description: Yates submits to a polygraph test administered by the FBI. The results are recorded as 'inconclusive' with no significant deception indicated.

sub_events.label: Jan 8, 1964
sub_events.title: Distressed Phone Call
sub_events.description: Yates calls SA C. Ray Hall late at night, crying and emotionally upset. He returns the next morning (Jan 9) to discuss his family's history of mental illness.

sub_events.label: Jan 15, 1964
sub_events.title: Final Appearance & Hospitalization
sub_events.description: Yates appears with his wife, carrying pills he claims his doctors are using to kill him. Following this visit, he is admitted to Woodlawn Hospital for psychiatric observation.

assertions.claim: Yates picked up a hitchhiker matching Oswald's description on Nov 20 or 21, 1963
assertions.analysis: FBI timeline analysis contradicts Yates' service call alibi

assertions.claim: The hitchhiker discussed shooting the President from a window
assertions.analysis: Detail emerged after assassination was widely known

assertions.claim: Yates experienced a mental health crisis following FBI interviews
assertions.analysis: Documented hospitalization at Woodlawn Hospital Jan 1964
Official FBI finding with no deception indicated

label: April 10, 1963 Â· Dallas, TX
title: The Walker Incident
description: An assassination attempt is made on General Edwin Walker at his home. A bullet is fired through his window, narrowly missing him. The Warren Commission later concluded Lee Harvey Oswald was the shooter.
context: General Edwin Walker, a controversial right-wing political figure, was the target of an assassination attempt at his Dallas home. A single shot was fired through a window while Walker sat at his desk. The bullet narrowly missed him, deflected by the window frame. Initially unsolved, the case was later connected to Lee Harvey Oswald based on testimony from his wife Marina and physical evidence.

sub_events.label: April 10, 1963 Â· 9:00 PM
sub_events.title: Shot fired through window
sub_events.description: Single shot fired at General Walker while he sat at his desk

sub_events.label: April 10, 1963 Â· 9:15 PM
sub_events.title: Dallas Police called
sub_events.description: Walker reports shooting to Dallas Police Department

sub_events.label: April 11-30, 1963
sub_events.title: Initial investigation
sub_events.description: Police conduct investigation but fail to identify shooter

sub_events.label: Dec 1963
sub_events.title: Marina Oswald revelation
sub_events.description: Marina tells FBI that Oswald confessed to shooting at Walker
